title: England 40-16 Australia: Jonny May scores two tries in Rugby World Cup 2019 quarter-finals
text:
Get the biggest daily news stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

Ruthless England powered their way into a first Rugby World Cup semi-final for 12 years on the back of a two-try display from Jonny May.

The Leicester winger celebrated his 50th cap in the best of ways by scoring twice in two minutes to set England on the road to a last-four clash against New Zealand or Ireland.

He was ably supported by Eddie Jones’ ‘Kamikaze kids’ Tom Curry and Sam Underhill, who enjoyed a sensational game in the loose.

Up against famed breakdown duo David Pocock and Michael Hooper, the youngsters took the game by the scruff of the neck in a performance which marked a changing of the guard

(Image: Getty Images)

(Image: Getty Images)

Australia had no answer as they were made to pay for eliminating England from their own World Cup four years ago, condemned to a four tries to one beating.

Yet nothing in the first quarter had given any indication that England would romp away to such an emphatic win.

Pinged at the scrum, unable to get a touch of the ball, they were forced to make 30 tackles in the first three minutes just to keep Australia at bay.

The Wallabies revelled in the open spaces, pushing and probing, with teenage rookie Jordon Petaia relishing his opportunity on the big stage.

(Image: PA)

(Image: PA)

When Kurtley Beale pounced on a Slade turnover and ran it back up the middle, alarm bells rang for England. Billy Vunipola went high, and Christian Lealiifano kicked Australia in front.

But England did not panic and after Anthony Watson made ground down the right, the ball tracked left, Manu Tuilagi ran a decoy and Tom Curry put May in for his first try. Before the Aussies could make sense of what had happened, May struck again.

This time it came from a fumble in the English 22, Slade picked up and bolted into open space. Closed down by defenders he kept his head, saw May level with him on the left and slipped a pin-point kick through the golden defensive line for May to run onto.

Farrell’s place had been called into question following a sub-par display against Argentina, particularly with the boot.

(Image: Getty Images,)

(Image: REUTERS)

How typical of the England captain that he should respond with 11 tackles and three perfect shots at goal to see his side into half-time leading 17-9.

As the players left the field Wonderwall rang out around the stadium as fin homage to the 2003 final, when England beat Australia and their players celebrated by belting out the Oasis classic.

But it was Australia who had most to get excited about moments lateral the game restarted and an Elliot Daly defensive horror show let them back into the game.

First the fullback fumbled a reception then, as Australia went left, with Reece Hodge throwing a divine pass out to Petaia, who slipped it expertly inside to Marika Koroibete, Daly showed the Fijian-born wing the outside and he emphatically took it.

(Image: AFLO/Press Association Images)

(Image: Getty Images)

Lealiifano’s conversion made it a one-point ball game but before Red Rose nerves could show themselves they were back in the box seat, Farrell picking out Sinckler with a sublime pass to put the prop over.

That was not quite that as England had to put in an incredible defensive set on their own line to repel one last Wallaby onslaught, before Sinckler turned the ball over.

From there the dye was cast. Farrell completed a perfect day with the boot to take the game away from the Wallabies, before Watson completed the rout with a late interception try.

(Image: Getty Images,)

England

Tries: May 2, Sinckler, Watson.

Cons: Farrell 4.

Pens: Farrell 4.

Australia

Try: Koroibete.

Con: Lealiifano.

Pens: Lealiifano 3.
description: Anthony Watson and Kyle Sinckler also went over as England reached the semi-finals in Japan
